It looks like you have a question about OpenAI API keys and how to revoke them if they do not appear in your organization's API key list.

**Here’s what you need to know:**

### 1. API Key Visibility
- **Personal API keys** (created by individual users) appear at https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys.
- **Organization-wide API keys** (created by admins) appear at https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys.

### 2. Revoking API Keys
- **You can only revoke API keys that you created or have permission to manage**. If you do not see a key in either location, you do not have permission to revoke it.
- **API keys are associated with the user or organization that created them.** If an employee leaves the company and their API keys are still active, you must either:
  - Have an admin remove the user from the organization (which revokes their keys)
  - Or, have the user log in and manually delete the key.

### 3. If a Key is Missing from Both Lists
- The key might have been created by a different user. Only the creator or an org admin can see and revoke it.
- If you are an admin, you might need to check with users in your organization to see who created the key.
- If the key is truly lost (e.g., created by a user who is no longer with the company and their account is deactivated), **you should contact OpenAI Support** for assistance: https://help.openai.com.

### 4. No API for Revoking Keys
- There is currently **no API endpoint** to list or revoke all organization keys; it must be done via the web interface.

---

**Summary Table:**

| Where Key Was Created             | Where to Revoke Key                                                               |
|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| User’s own account                | https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys (user must log in)          |
| Organization (by admin)           | https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys (org admin required)   |

---

**Action Steps:**

1. **Verify** who created the key and ask them to revoke it.
2. **If the user is gone,** remove them from your OpenAI org (admin action) to automatically revoke their keys.
3. **If you cannot find the key/creator,** contact OpenAI Support for help.

---

**References:**
- [OpenAI API key management docs](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/api-keys)
- [OpenAI Help Center](https://help.openai.com)

---

**If you need a template for contacting OpenAI Support, let me know!**

API keys on OpenAI are typically managed at the user (profile) level (https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys), rather than the organization level. The organization settings page does not show or manage API keys directly.

- As a last resort, consider rotating any credentials or secrets that might be at risk, and restrict access via your application’s own security settings (e.g., IP allowlists, usage monitoring).

If you have API keys that aren't showing up in the OpenAI platform interface, here are several approaches to resolve this:

## 1. **Check Different API Key Locations**
OpenAI has two different places where API keys might be stored:
- **Personal API keys**: `https://platform.openai.com/api-keys`
- **Organization API keys**: `https://platform.openai.com/account/api-keys`

Make sure you're checking both locations, as keys created at different levels may appear in different places.

## 2. **Use the OpenAI API to List Keys**
You can programmatically list all API keys using the OpenAI API itself:

```bash
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/api-keys \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY" \
  -H "OpenAI-Beta: assistants=v1"
```

## 3. **Contact OpenAI Support**
If keys are genuinely missing from the interface:
- Email: support@openai.com
- Use the help chat on their platform
- Submit a support ticket through their platform

When contacting support, provide:
- Your organization ID
- Approximate date when the keys were created
- Any partial key information you have (first few characters)

## 4. **Security Best Practices**
If you suspect keys may be compromised:
- **Immediately rotate all keys** you do have access to
- **Monitor your usage** for any unauthorized activity
- **Implement key rotation policies** going forward

## 5. **Alternative Solutions**
- Consider implementing a proxy layer between your application and OpenAI
- Use environment-specific keys that can be rotated independently
- Implement key management through your own infrastructure

---

Section 3.2: Request Processing

**Requirement**  
At my company, we have API keys that are not shown in https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys and as a result, we cannot revoke them. Does somebody know of another way to revoke an API key? Thanks a lot in advance for your replies!

**Implementation**  
OpenAI currently only allows you to view and revoke API keys that are visible in your user or organization dashboard:

- Personal keys: https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys  
- Organization keys: https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys

If an API key is not listed in either location, it generally means one of the following:

- The key was created under a different account or user profile.
- The key was deleted, but is still being used in code/configuration.
- There is a display issue—try logging out and back in, clearing browser cache, or using another browser.

**Actions to Take:**

1. **Check All Accounts**:  
   Ensure you are signed in with the correct account (personal vs. organization). If multiple admins exist, ask them to check their dashboards as well.

2. **Contact OpenAI Support**:  
   If the key is not visible and you cannot revoke it, the only way to revoke it is to contact OpenAI support directly:
   - Go to https://help.openai.com/ and submit a request.
   - Provide the key (or at least the prefix), explain the situation, and ask for it to be revoked.

3. **Audit and Rotate**:  
   - Rotate (regenerate) any keys that may have been exposed.
   - Update your systems to use only keys you control.
   - Remove old or orphaned credentials from code, configuration files, and environment variables.

**OpenAI Notes:**  
There is no self-service or API endpoint to revoke keys not visible in your dashboard as of June 2024. Only OpenAI support can assist with “ghost” or orphaned API key revocations.

**Validation**  
- Automated tests must ensure that only active, valid API keys are accepted by the system.
- Any change in API key validity (revocation, rotation) should immediately be reflected in request authorization checks.
- Periodic audits should be performed to verify all keys in use are visible and managed.

---

**Summary Table**

| Step                        | Responsible Party | Action                                                               |
|-----------------------------|------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Check all account dashboards| All admins       | Verify visibility of all API keys.                                   |
| Contact OpenAI support      | Designated admin | Request revocation of invisible API keys, providing key prefix.      |
| Audit and rotate keys       | DevOps/Security  | Remove unused keys, rotate as needed, update configurations.         |
| Automated validation        | QA               | Test that requests with revoked keys are rejected by the system.     |

---

If you need a sample support message or further details on technical implementation, let me know!

azure-o1.response:
Section 3.2: Request Processing

1. Requirement  
   At our company, we have certain OpenAI API keys in use that do not appear under our organization’s API keys page (https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys). Consequently, we cannot revoke them via the standard interface. We need guidance or an alternative procedure to revoke these “invisible” keys to maintain proper security and compliance controls.

2. Analysis  
   • Typical Revocation Method:  
     – Normally, OpenAI API keys may be revoked by navigating to the “API keys” section in the OpenAI platform. If a key does not appear there, it can’t be directly revoked through the standard user interface.  
   • Potential Causes:  
     – The API keys might belong to another organization or account.  
     – They could have been created under a different user profile.  
     – They may have been created via older (now-deprecated) workflows and not carried over into the current interface.  
   • Risk Implications:  
     – If keys remain active and unreadable or unrevokeable in the user portal, there is a risk of unauthorized access to company or customer data.  
     – Not having a clear record of all active keys may violate internal security policies or regulatory requirements.

3. Implementation  
   The following steps should help address or mitigate the issue of API keys not appearing in the user portal:

   a) Verify Organization and User Accounts  
      – Confirm that the API key in question is associated with the correct organization or user account. Sometimes, keys used by service accounts or other organizations won’t appear in your personal or main organization’s API key list.

   b) Check Internal Key Management Systems  
      – If your company maintains an internal secrets manager, CI/CD pipeline, or enterprise password vault, verify whether the key is stored there. An internal rotation or revocation mechanism may be possible even if the key isn’t visible in the OpenAI dashboard.

   c) Contact OpenAI Support  
      – If you have exhausted the above steps and still cannot locate the keys in any associated account, open a support ticket with OpenAI. Provide them with any known information about the key usage (e.g., approximate creation time, usage patterns, potential user or service account).  
      – OpenAI Support may offer additional checks or forcibly revoke the key on the backend, if they can verify ownership and usage details.

   d) Plan for Key Rotation  
      – As part of ongoing security best practices, implement regular key rotations. Use a job or a security tool to rotate all known API keys—this helps discover “unknown” or orphaned keys that remain active but untracked.  
      – Document each rotation event to ensure you have an updated inventory of all valid keys.

   e) Governance and Policy Enforcement  
      – Enforce policies disallowing the creation of untracked keys (e.g., only allowing generation via an approved service account, or requiring use of a central secrets vault).  
      – Integrate policy checks that detect usage of unrecognized keys (for instance, by analyzing usage logs or billing records).

4. Validation  
   Automated and manual testing should be in place to ensure that:  
   • Any newly generated API key is properly stored, tracked, and can be revoked on demand.  
   • Security alerts are provided when an unrecognized API key is used in any environment.  
   • Regular audits confirm that all keys used are visible in the authorized key management system.

By following these steps and instituting appropriate security governance, the system will ensure all API keys—including those not currently visible in the OpenAI dashboard—can be discovered, managed, and revoked as needed.

Below is an example of a system design document section (Section 3.2: Request Processing) that addresses API key revocation given the constraints described. You can adapt this to your project’s overall documentation framework.

──────────────────────────────
Section 3.2: Request Processing

Overview:
  This section defines how API requests will be authenticated, processed, and validated using API keys. It also addresses challenges around revocation of API keys which are not visible within the standard organization-level API key management interface (https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys).

Requirement Background:
  • Our current API key management workflow is split between organization-level keys (visible at https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys) and user-level API keys (visible at https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys).  
  • Certain API keys in use within our company are not listed in the organization portal. This limitation prevents us from being able to revoke them directly via the organization’s UI.
  • The objective is to securely process requests using these keys while providing a mechanism for timely revocation when necessary.

Design Considerations & Alternatives:
  1. Standard Protocols:  
      The system shall utilize industry-standard protocols for authentication and request processing (for example, using JWT tokens, OAuth2, or HMAC-based request signing as applicable).
      • Using standard protocols simplifies integration with third-party tools and supports automated testing.
      • If key rotation or decommissioning is needed, the API workflow should support protocol-driven revocation.

  2. API Key Revocation Strategies:  
      Because the standard organization-level API key management page does not list all issued keys, alternative approaches include:  
      a. User-Level Settings:  
       • Direct key management through individual user profiles (via https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys).  
      • Ensure that any key issued is logged and also reflective in user-specific settings to allow immediate revocation when necessary.
      b. Programmatic Revocation Endpoint:  
      • Implement a dedicated revocation endpoint as part of the system where API keys can be flagged as “revoked” without requiring them to appear in the primary organization UI.  
      • This endpoint should validate caller permissions (using standard auth protocols) and update the key’s status in the database.
      c. Key Rotation Mechanism:  
      • Introduce a mechanism for scheduled key rotation.  
      • For any API keys that may have been inadvertently exposed or compromised (especially those not visible in the organization view), a rotation schedule would automatically update and invalidate older credentials.

  3. Backward Compatibility and Legacy Keys:  
      • For keys already in use that are not managed via the organization portal, provide a migration or linking mechanism so that their status can be tracked.  
      • This may include synchronizing the backend database with user profile key management, ensuring that any issued key (regardless of how it appears) can be controlled.

Implementation:
  • All API request processing and key validation modules shall be built using standard cryptographic protocols and secure messaging standards (e.g., TLS).

I understand you're having trouble revoking API keys that aren't visible in the OpenAI dashboard. Here are several approaches to resolve this issue:

## Immediate Solutions

### 1. Check Alternative Dashboard Locations
- **Organization vs Personal Keys**: Verify you're checking both:
  - Personal API keys: `https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys`
  - Organization API keys: `https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys`
- **Switch Organization Context**: If you're part of multiple organizations, ensure you're viewing the correct one using the organization selector

### 2. Contact OpenAI Support
- **Direct Support Request**: Submit a ticket at `https://help.openai.com/`
- **Provide Key Details**: Include:
  - Partial key identifier (first/last few characters)
  - Approximate creation date
  - Organization ID
  - Use case description

### 3. API-Based Verification
```bash
# Test if a key is still active
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/models \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY"
```

## System Design Considerations

### Request Processing Architecture
```
┌─────────────────┐    ┌──────────────────┐    ┌─────────────────┐
│   API Gateway   │───▶│  Key Validation  │───▶│  Rate Limiting  │
│                 │    │     Service      │    │    Service      │
└─────────────────┘    └──────────────────┘    └─────────────────┘
```

### Implementation Requirements
- **Key Lifecycle Management**: Implement proper key rotation policies
- **Audit Trail**: Maintain logs of all API key operations
- **Access Control**: Role-based permissions for key management
- **Monitoring**: Real-time tracking of key usage patterns

### Validation Framework
```python
class APIKeyValidator:
    def __init__(self):
        self.active_keys = set()
        self.revoked_keys = set()
    
    def validate_key(self, api_key):
        if api_key in self.revoked_keys:
            return False, "Key has been revoked"
        return True, "Key is valid"
    
    def revoke_key(self, api_key):
        self.revoked_keys.add(api_key)
        self.active_keys.discard(api_key)
```

## Preventive Measures

### 1. Key Management Best Practices
- **Centralized Inventory**: Maintain a registry of all issued keys
- **Regular Audits**: Periodic review of active keys
- **Automated Rotation**: Implement scheduled key rotation
- **Environment Separation**: Different keys for dev/staging/production

### 2. Monitoring Implementation
- **Usage Analytics**: Track API calls per key
- **Anomaly Detection**: Identify unusual usage patterns
- **Compliance Reporting**: Generate key usage reports

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these approaches or help you implement a specific solution?

Below is the most relevant information found regarding the question “At my company we have API keys that are not shown in https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys and as a result we cannot revoke them. Does somebody know of another way to revoke an API key?”

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
ANSWER/INFORMATION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
1. If an API key was originally created in a personal account (rather than under the organization), that key will only appear on the “Profile” → “API Keys” page for the user who generated it, not on the organization-level page. You may wish to confirm each team member’s individual “Profile” → “API Keys” page at:
   https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys

2. Organization owners can typically see and manage all the keys created under the organization in “Organization Settings” → “API Keys.” However, if a key was generated by someone who is no longer with the company or by an account that has since been removed, that key may be inaccessible for direct revocation via the web UI.

3. If the key does not appear under your organization and you cannot find the user account that created it, you can reach out to OpenAI’s support (via the Help Center at https://help.openai.com/). Provide them with the relevant details (e.g., the key prefix, your organization ID) and request that they revoke or remove unused or lost keys that are not visible to you.

4. As a best practice, ensure each user generates their own API key instead of sharing personal or organization-wide keys. This makes it easier to manage and revoke keys when personnel changes occur or when a key is no longer needed.

5. If you have administrative access to the account of the team member who originally generated the key, log in as that user (or ask them to log in) and manually revoke it from their “Profile” → “API Keys” page. That is the most direct way to remove a key not visible on the organization page.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
RECOMMENDATION
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
• Verify which account was used to create the missing API key(s).  
• Have that user—or an admin who can access that user’s account—revoke the key from the “Profile” → “API Keys” page.  
• If ownership cannot be traced or you do not have access to the creator’s account, contact OpenAI support with the pertinent details so they can assist in revoking the key.

3. Check for team vs. personal keys
   – Sometimes the API key may have been created by a colleague under a personal account rather than the organization’s shared account. If that’s the case, the user who created the key must revoke it from their own “API keys” page under their personal account.

4. Remove the key from all codebases and environment variables
   – Even if you cannot revoke the key through the dashboard, removing any references to it in code or configuration files effectively stops usage from your side. Ensure it’s not stored in version control or any environment variables.

5. Contact OpenAI Support if you still cannot revoke

If an API key isn’t showing up in your organization’s API Keys page and you’re unable to revoke it as a result, here are a few suggestions you can try:

1. Check if you are in the correct organization or multiple organizations:
   • Make sure you’re viewing the correct organization in the OpenAI platform. If you belong to multiple organizations, the API key in question might have been created under a different one.  
   • Use the organization switcher in the top-right corner (or on the left menu, depending on your view) to confirm you’re in the right place.

2. Confirm who created the key:
   • Each personal API key is tied to the individual user who generated it. If a teammate created the key under their own account rather than under a shared organization account, it won’t show up in your personal list or your organization’s list.  
   • If possible, have the teammate who originally generated the key sign in and revoke it from their own settings.

3. Contact your workspace/organization admins:
   • Individuals with an owner or admin role on your OpenAI organization may have broader access. If your account doesn’t have sufficient permissions, an admin might be able to see and revoke keys that general members cannot.

4. Rotate or remove the key at your code/infrastructure level:
   • If the key was embedded in your company’s code, secrets manager, CI/CD pipeline, or environment variables, remove or replace it to effectively disable usage—even if you can’t see it in the OpenAI dashboard. This ensures the key no longer works in your systems.

5. Reach out to OpenAI Support:
   • If you’ve confirmed that the key was created under your organization (or by a user who is no longer at your company) and you still don’t see any way to revoke it, the official support channel can help track down and remove unseen or orphaned keys.

In most cases, simply locating the user who originally created the key (or switching to the correct organization) will reveal the key so it can be revoked. If no one in your organization can see it, contacting OpenAI Support is the surest way to resolve the issue.

It looks like you’re asking about how to revoke OpenAI API keys that are not visible on your organization’s API keys page (https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys), so you cannot revoke them using the standard interface.

Here’s what you can do:

1. Double-check User vs. Organization Keys:
- User Keys: Visit https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys – these are keys created for your personal user account.
- Organization Keys: Visit https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys – these are keys created for your organization.

A key will only appear in the interface where it was created.

2. API Key Visibility:
- You can only view and revoke keys you created yourself.
- If the key was created by another member of your organization, only that user or an organization owner/admin can see and revoke it.

3. If the Key Does Not Appear:
- If it’s not visible in either your user or organization settings, and you do not have admin access:
  - Contact your OpenAI organization administrator. They may have created or have access to revoke the key.
  - If you are the admin and still can’t see it, it’s possible the key was created in a different user account or organization.

4. Contact OpenAI Support:
- If you can’t locate or revoke the key through the interface, open a support request with OpenAI: https://platform.openai.com/help
- Provide them with as much information as possible about the key and the account/organization.

5. Preventative Steps:
- Rotate any secrets or credentials that may have been exposed or are at risk.
- Audit the usage of your keys via OpenAI’s usage dashboards.

Summary Table:

| Situation                                                   | Solution                                   |
|-------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------|
| Key is in your user profile                                 | Revoke from user API keys page             |
| Key is in your organization and you’re admin                | Revoke from organization API keys page     |
| Key is not visible and you’re not admin                     | Contact organization admin                 |
| Key is not visible and you are admin                        | Contact OpenAI support                     |

If you provide more details about your role (user or admin) and where the key was created, I can give more specific guidance.

# API Endpoint Documentation

## Create a Request

Creates a new request in the system.

### Endpoint

```
POST /api/v1/requests
```

### Headers

- `Content-Type: application/json` (required)

### Request Body Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Required | Description |
|-----------|------|----------|-------------|
| task | string | Yes | The description of the task or request. |
| priority | string | No | The priority level of the request. Valid values: "low", "normal", "high". Defaults to "normal" if not specified. |
| async | boolean | No | Whether the request should be processed asynchronously. Defaults to false if not specified. |

### Response

#### Success (200 OK)

```json
{
  "status": "processed",
  "id": "req-123"
}
```

- `status`: The status of the request processing. Possible values include "processed", "pending", or "failed".
- `id`: A unique identifier for the created request.

#### Possible Error Responses

- `400 Bad Request`: Invalid request parameters
- `401 Unauthorized`: Authentication failure
- `429 Too Many Requests`: Rate limit exceeded
- `500 Internal Server Error`: Server-side error

### Example Usage

```bash
curl -X POST https://example.com/api/v1/requests \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "task": "Your task description here",
    "priority": "normal",
    "async": false
  }'
```

Based on your question about revoking OpenAI API keys that aren't showing up in the dashboard, here are several approaches you can try:

## Primary Solutions

### 1. Check Different Dashboard Locations
- **Organization API Keys**: https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys
- **Personal API Keys**: https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys
- **Project-specific Keys**: Check individual project settings if using project-based API keys

### 2. Contact OpenAI Support Directly
- Go to https://help.openai.com/
- Submit a support ticket with:
  - Your organization ID
  - Partial API key identifiers (first/last few characters)
  - When the keys were created
  - Why you need them revoked

### 3. API Key Management via API
If you have admin access, you can use OpenAI's API to list and manage keys:
```bash
curl -X GET "https://api.openai.com/v1/organization/api_keys" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ADMIN_KEY"
```

### 4. Organization Admin Actions
- Ensure you're logged in as an organization admin
- Check if keys were created under a different user account
- Review organization member permissions

## Additional Steps

### Security Measures
1. **Rotate all visible keys** as a precaution
2. **Monitor usage** in the billing/usage dashboard
3. **Review organization audit logs** if available
4. **Update applications** to use new keys

### Prevention
- Document all API key creation
- Use project-scoped keys when possible
- Implement regular key rotation policies
- Assign key management to specific team members

If none of these methods work, OpenAI support is your best option as they can access backend systems to locate and revoke keys that aren't visible in the UI.

- **Rotate all known keys** - Create new keys and update your applications
- **Monitor usage** - Check your usage dashboard for unexpected activity

- **Enable IP restrictions** - If available for your plan

Your regular expression is extremely specific and is designed to match only a *very* particular phrase, with every word and even the URL written in a way that allows for any combination of upper- and lowercase letters.

### Review & Feedback

#### 1. **Pattern Purpose**
Your regex matches this (or very similar) text, regardless of capitalization:

> At my company we have API keys that are not shown in https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys and as a result we cannot revoke them. Does somebody know of another way to revoke an API key? Thanks a lot in advance for your replies!  
> https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys

#### 2. **Flags**
You list `gi` (global and case-insensitive).  
**Note:** Because you explicitly allow for [aA] etc., the `i` flag is redundant here. If you use `/pattern/gi`, you can just write `a` instead of `[aA]` and so on.

#### 3. **Pattern Efficiency**
- **Readability:** Your pattern is very long, repetitive, and hard to maintain.
- **Maintainability:** If the text changes even slightly (additional/missing space, punctuation, etc.), it will **not match**.
- **Overly Specific:** It will only match this *exact* text.

#### 4. **Suggested Improvements**
If your goal is to match *this type of request in general* (about API keys not being shown/revoked), you can make the pattern much more flexible and resilient.

##### **Example Flexible Pattern**
```regex
at my company.*api key.*not shown.*openai\.com/settings/organization/api-keys.*cannot revoke
```
- Add `i` flag for case-insensitivity.
- Use `.*` for any text in between.
- Escape dots in URLs.
- This will match similar requests, not just this exact one.

##### **If You Want Only Exact Text**
- Use the exact phrase, and just `i` flag:
```regex
At my company we have api keys that are not shown in https://platform.openai.com/settings/organization/api-keys and as a result we cannot revoke them. Does somebody know of another way to revoke an api key\? Thanks a lot in advance for your replies!
https://platform.openai.com/settings/profile/api-keys
```
With `/.../i` flag, it matches regardless of case.

#### 5. **Summary Table**

| Aspect           | Your Pattern          | Recommended Pattern            |
|------------------|----------------------|-------------------------------|
| Case Sensitivity | Manual, via [aA]     | Use `i` flag                  |
| Flexibility      | Inflexible           | Use `.*` for variation        |
| Maintainability  | Hard                 | Easy                          |
| Readability      | Poor                 | Good                          |

---

### **Final Recommendations**

- **Use the `i` flag** for case-insensitivity; omit `[aA]` etc.
- **Add wildcards** if you want to match *similar* requests, not just this one.
- **Escape special characters** in URLs.
- **Keep your regex maintainable and readable.**

---

#### **Example: Flexible, Case-Insensitive**
```regex
at my company.*api key.*not shown.*openai\.com/settings/organization/api-keys.*cannot revoke
```
with `i` flag.

---

**If you need a regex for a different purpose, or want it to extract/match something else, please clarify!**

Below is a concise explanation and a simplified version of the regex. The original pattern is essentially matching that entire block of text literally (including punctuation and spacing), with each character bracketed to allow for case‐insensitive matching. Since you’re using the “i” (case‐insensitive) flag, you don’t need to bracket each letter manually.

───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) Explanation of the Original Pattern
───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
• [aA][tT] : Matches “at” or “At” (etc.)
• \s+      : Matches one or more whitespace characters.
• [mM][yY] : Matches “my,” ignoring case.
• …        : Repeats the bracketed‐letter approach for each word/letter.
• https:\/\/platform\.openai\.com\/settings\/organization\/api-keysand :
  A literal match of the URL (with dots and slashes escaped) plus the “and.”
• …        : Continues matching the exact sequence of letters/words.
• Flags:
  - g (global) means it will find all non‐overlapping occurrences in a larger text.
  - i (case-insensitive) means uppercase/lowercase doesn’t matter anywhere in the pattern.

Because each character is bracketed ([aA]) and the “i” flag is on, you are effectively duplicating the case‐insensitivity. You can simplify this greatly by writing the text in one shot, escaping only symbols that need it (like “.”), and relying on /i for case insensitivity.

───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) A Simplified Case‐Insensitive Version
───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

/at my company we have api keys that are not shown in https:\/\/platform\.openai\.com\/settings\/organization\/api-keysand as a result we cannot revoke them\. does somebody know of another way to revoke an api key\? thanks a lot in advance for your replies\! https:\/\/platform\.openai\.com\/settings\/profile\/api-keys/gi

Key points in the simplified pattern:
• Use literal text, then escape special regex metacharacters (the dots “.” and the slashes “/”).
• The “i” flag automatically handles uppercase vs. lowercase.
• You can match spaces by typing them as literal spaces or use \s where appropriate.
• Because you’re matching a large block of text, be mindful of punctuation (the question mark, exclamation mark, etc.)—make sure to escape those if needed (\? and \!).

By consolidating into a single pattern with the “i” flag, you avoid having to write [aA], [tT], etc. for each letter.
